ohms law: Ohm’s Law states that the current flowing through a conductor is directly proportional to the voltage across it, provided temperature remains constant. V = I × R. It forms the basic relationship of current, voltage, and resistance and is used in circuit analysis.
kirchhoff voltage law: KVL states that the algebraic sum of voltages in any closed loop is zero. Applied to mesh analysis and energy conservation in circuits.
kirchhoff current law: KCL states that algebraic sum of currents at a node is zero. Total current entering equals total leaving. Used in nodal analysis.
capacitor: A capacitor stores electrical energy in an electric field between conducting plates separated by a dielectric. C = εA/d. Used in filtering, timing circuits, coupling/decoupling, tuning circuits.
inductor: An inductor stores energy in a magnetic field. Voltage across inductor V = L(di/dt). Used in filters, tuned circuits, switching regulators and RF designs.
resistor: A resistor opposes current flow and provides voltage drops. R = ρL/A. Used for biasing, current limiting and sensing.
semiconductor: A semiconductor is a material whose conductivity lies between conductor and insulator. Examples: Silicon, Germanium. Doping creates P and N type regions enabling diodes and transistors.
pn junction: A PN junction forms when P and N regions meet causing diffusion and formation of depletion region. Exhibits conduction in forward bias and blocking in reverse bias.
zener diode: A diode designed to operate in reverse breakdown at specific breakdown voltage used in voltage regulation.
bjt: A Bipolar Junction Transistor is a current controlled device. Regions: emitter, base, collector. BJT can work in active, saturation and cutoff regions for amplification and switching.
mosfet: MOSFET is a voltage-controlled FET having high input impedance and fast switching. Used in power electronics, digital ICs and RF circuits.
rectifier: A circuit which converts AC to DC using diodes. Half-wave uses single diode, full-wave uses center tap or bridge configuration. Ripple reduced by filters.
filter: Filters allow desired frequency band and reject unwanted components. Types: low-pass, high-pass, band-pass, band-stop. Implemented using RLC or active op-amp circuits.
clamping circuit: Shifts the DC level of a signal without changing amplitude. Used for restoring DC level and wave shaping.
clipping circuit: Limits the amplitude of a signal beyond a reference voltage. Used for protection and wave shaping.
operational amplifier: An Op-Amp is a high gain differential amplifier with very high input impedance and very low output impedance. Used in amplifiers, integrators, differentiators, active filters, oscillators and ADC/DAC interface.
logic gate: A digital circuit that performs Boolean function. Basic gates: AND, OR, NOT. Universal gates: NAND, NOR. Used in digital logic design.
flip flop: Bistable element storing 1-bit. Types: SR, JK, D, T. Used in registers, counters and sequential circuits.
counter: Sequential circuits that count pulses. Up/down, synchronous/asynchronous. Used in timers, frequency division and event counting.
register: Group of flip-flops storing binary data used inside CPUs for temporary data, instructions, flags etc.
number systems: Represent numbers in binary, octal, decimal and hexadecimal systems. Conversion techniques form basis of digital design.
boolean algebra: Mathematical representation of logic using variables and operations (AND, OR, NOT). Simplification using laws and theorems improves circuit efficiency.
k map: Karnaugh Map graphical method used to minimize Boolean expressions to reduce digital logic hardware.
adder: Circuit adding binary digits. Half adder handles two bits without carry in; full adder includes carry. Used in ALU and processors.
microprocessor: Programmable device that fetches, decodes and executes instructions. Contains ALU, registers, control unit but external memory and I/O required.
microcontroller: Single-chip processor containing CPU, RAM, ROM, timers and peripherals designed for embedded system applications like automation, robotics, consumer electronics.
8051 microcontroller: 8-bit MCS-51 family MCU with Harvard architecture, on-chip timers, ports, serial interface and interrupts. Used in many embedded platforms.
adc: Analog to Digital Converter converts analog voltage into binary representation. Types: flash, SAR, dual slope.
dac: Digital to Analog Converter converts binary input to analog output. Used in sound synthesis, control systems and instrumentation.
control system: A system that maintains desired output by automatically adjusting inputs. Types: open loop and closed loop. Stability analysis uses transfer functions and root locus.
feedback: Process of feeding output portion back to input. Reduces errors, improves stability and bandwidth.
transfer function: Laplace domain ratio of output to input assuming zero initial conditions. Used for system analysis, poles define stability.
laplace transform: Transforms differential time domain equations into algebraic s-domain representation simplifying system analysis.
fourier transform: Transforms signal from time to frequency domain revealing spectrum content essential in communication and signal processing.
z transform: Discrete-time counterpart of Laplace used for DSP system analysis, stability and filter design.
amplitude modulation: Modulation technique where amplitude of carrier varies with message. Used in broadcast radio. Sensitive to noise.
frequency modulation: Carrier frequency changes with message. Better noise immunity than AM. Used in FM radio and wireless communication.
phase modulation: Modifies carrier phase using message. Basis for digital modulation methods like PSK.
digital modulation: Uses discrete symbol levels such as ASK, PSK, QAM. Information carried in amplitude/phase combinations.
multiplexing: Combining multiple signals into single channel. TDM uses time slots; FDM uses different frequency bands.
communication system: Contains transmitter, channel and receiver. Channel introduces attenuation, distortion and noise affecting received signal.
noise: Any unwanted signal interfering with original. Measured by SNR. Types: thermal, interference, shot noise.
antenna: Device converting electrical signals into electromagnetic waves and vice versa. Characteristics include gain, directivity, radiation pattern, bandwidth.
radiation pattern: Spatial distribution of radiated energy showing direction of maximum radiation. Used to design antennas for mobile and satellite links.
waveguide: Hollow metallic structure guiding microwave signals with low loss used in radar and satellite communication.
radar: Radio Detection and Ranging uses microwave signals to detect distance, direction and velocity using Doppler principle.
dsp: Digital Signal Processing involves sampling, quantization, filtering, DFT/FFT, spectral analysis and real-time implementation using DSP processors.
convolution: Fundamental DSP operation combining signals to produce output representing weighted sum. Used for filtering and system analysis.
fft: Fast Fourier Transform computes DFT efficiently enabling real-time spectrum computation used in OFDM and modulation.
sampling: Converts continuous signal to discrete time by taking samples. Nyquist theorem says Fs ≥2×fmax.
quantization: Approximating amplitudes to discrete levels causing quantization noise. Step size Δ controls distortion.
dpcm: Differential Pulse Code Modulation encodes difference between samples reducing bit rate.
microstrip patch antenna: Low profile antenna printed on dielectric substrate, offers directional radiation, easy fabrication, widely used in WLAN, Bluetooth, mobile communication.
smith chart: Graphical tool for solving transmission line impedance matching problems using reflection coefficient diagrams.
vlsi: Very Large Scale Integration involves designing millions of MOSFETs in a single chip. Comprises CMOS technology, layout, fabrication, timing, verification.
cmos inverter: Basic CMOS logic building block using PMOS and NMOS providing high noise margin and low static power.
power electronics: Deals with conversion and control of electrical power using semiconductor devices such as SCR, MOSFET, IGBT. Applications include drives, UPS, SMPS.
smps: Switched Mode Power Supply uses switching regulators for efficient power conversion at high frequency offering smaller size and better efficiency.
